Developed software for Compatibility and System Validation (CV and SV) of Intel processors and chipsets in Visual Studio development environment, and Perl scripts and Lira under Linux to parse the RTL (Verilog, System Verilog) to determine hardware infrastructure.

Received Divisional Recognition Award for creating NoaView tool for validating Sandy Bridge and Ivy Bridge processors (Intel® Core™ Gen2 and Gen3 processors).

Senior Software Engineer Intel Corporation August 1991  –  July 1994  (3 years) Folsom, CA Developed BIOS, firmware, and driver software for the Communications Product Division supporting the new PCMCIA (Personal Computer Memory Card International Association - aka PC Cards) specification using C and assembly language in MS-DOS and Windows environments.

Developed firmware for Motorola 68302 micro-controller based laptop fax-modem cards. 
 
Developed ODI (Open Data-link Interface) and NDIS (Network Driver Interface Specification) drivers for laptop LAN cards.

Revitalized an aging Motorola 6809 based voice mail product; devised patented firmware that allowed dependable voice detection, enabling the implementation of Automated Attendant product. 
 
Maintained a Motorola 68010 VME based voice mail product; improved the SCSI disk device driver achieving 115% improvement in disk I/O throughput, solved several serial I/O device driver issues, improved phone interface card firmware, and ported patented voice detect algorithm. 
 
Worked closely with Marketing and Customer Service departments to determine software requirements and specifications. Summary Hamid R. Rabiee - Received his BS and MS degrees (with Great Distinction) in Electrical Engineering from CSULB, his EEE degree in Electrical and Computer Engineering from USC, and his PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering from Purdue University, West Lafayette, USA in 1996. From 1993 to 1996 he was a Member of Technical Staff at AT&T Bell Laboratories. From 1996 to 1999 he worked as a Senior Software Engineer at Intel Corporation. He was also with PSU, OGI and OSU universities as an adjunct professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering from 1996-2000. Since September 2000, he has joined Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran. He is the founder of Sharif University Advanced Information and Communication Technology Research Center (AICT), Advanced Technologies Incubator (SATI), Digital Media Laboratory (DML), and Mobile Value Added Services Laboratory (M-VASL). He is currently a Professor of Computer Engineering at Sharif University of Technology, and the Director of AICT, DML, and M-VASL. He has been the initiator and director of national and international level projects in the context of UNDP International Open Source Network (IOSN) and Iran National ICT Development Plan. Prof. Rabiee has received numerous awards and honors for his Industrial, scientific and academic contributions. He has acted as chairman in a number of national and international conferences, and holds three patents. He is also a Senior Member of IEEE. Summary Hamid R. Summary I am a seasoned Software Engineer that has been designing and developing software since 1995, primarily on the Microsoft stack. I started with Visual C++ 1.0, Visual Basic 3.0 (for Windows) and 1.0 (for DOS), and SQL Server 4.2. 
 
I have followed application development trends from client/server to n-tier to web to mobile to the cloud. Clients started thick, then went thin, then alternated several times between the two. Business logic migrated from stored procedures to COM components to services. Data modeling shifted from 3rd party tools to SQL database diagrams to ORMs. 
 
For a good part of my career I was very active in the Microsoft certification community. From 1996 to 2010, I passed 32 exams and attained (and re-attained) the major developer and database certifications. In 2004 I became a Microsoft Certified Trainer. From 2005 to 2010, I taught 21 developer and database-oriented classes to 265 students, saving my company $435K. 
 
After acquiring vast experience developing enterprise applications and establishing a successful track record of solving complex problems, I am now squarely in the second half of my career. Though I no longer code as often, my project responsibilities have nonetheless increased by managing the project schedule, technical team, customers, and management. 
 
I have been employed by Intel since 2000, and most recently I joined the Internet of Things Group. I am currently part of the development team working on Retail Client Manager (intel.com/rcm), and I am having a lot of fun. I am not looking for any other opportunities at this time. Summary I have an extensive background in software design and development. I have served as a software engineer, team lead, and personnel manager during my tenure at Intel depending on what was needed by the organization that I work for. I have developed software for many flavors of Unix and Linux as well as 32 bit Windows dating back to Windows 95. Part of my career as an engineer was spent working in a research and development group at Intel that was pioneering the use of computers in the home as well as developing new applications that harnessed the Internet, which at the time was just hitting the mainstream. I was involved in some very early experiments integrating television content into computer applications. Right now I am very interested in mobile internet devices, and helping to shape the future of this growing technology area. I am interested in working as a software engineer or as a hands-on software architect.
